newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: Lithuania election to dictate T-bill rates - broker.
newsitem.headline: Lithuania election to dictate T-bill rates - broker.

text.p: Rates on Lithuania's Treasury bills will continue falling until the parliamentary elections in October but could then rise on concerns about a possible litas devaluation, Lithuanian broker Suprema said on Wednesday.
Suprema said in its monthly market forecast that concerns about a possible litas devaluation would scare off foreign investors and drive back T-bill rates back up.
"The foreign share in the market may decrease from 40 to 10-15 percent if the current opposition, which is clamouring for a litas devaluation, wins at the polls," Suprema said.
"Any serious rumour about a litas devaluation would substantially affect the T-bill market and rates would quickly begin moving up."
The conservative parliamentary opposition has said that it favours a litas devaluation or "revaluation".
Lithuania's T-bill rates have fallen steadily in recent months after rising sharply in the wake of a banking crisis.
Rates reached almost 40 percent in February but this week the average rate on 91-day paper was 11.08 percent.
Suprema said it did not expect yields to fall below about seven percent.
Suprema said domestic banks with international equity issues were behind the unexpectedly high demand in July and August which brought yields down.
Suprema said the banks had no other place to immediately put the money and so they invested in domestic T-bills.
